docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: IT IS 10 A.M. ON A MONDAY, and the Surgeon General is already at war. C. Everett Koop is addressing a room choked with reporters at the Department of Health and Human Services. As he stands with Amish severity in his Navy uniform, jabbing his pointer at poster-sized graphs and charts, Koop looks less like a spokesman for national health than a commodore outlining his battle plans.
